awd_titl_txt: The Study of Nuclear Physics with Intermediate Energy Probes
awd_abstract_narration:
Our research program at the University of South Carolina is based at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility in Newport News, Virginia.  There, we use high-energy electron and photon beams along with sophisticated particle detectors as powerful microscopes to study the subatomic world.  We try to answer questions like: What is the structure of the nucleon?  What are and how can we excite its internal degrees of freedom?  Once excited, in which way does the nucleon decay back to its original state?  Does the structure of the nucleon change if it is embedded in dense nuclear matter?  Do other subatomic particles change their properties if they are produced in dense nuclear matter?  The experimental study of these properties gives insight into the nature of the strong force and allows for rigorous tests of the underlying theory.

Almost the entire mass of an atom is concentrated in its tiny nucleus.  The atomic nucleus is made of nucleons, which are either positively charged (protons) or electrically neutral (neutrons).  These subatomic particles, however, are not elementary but are themselves composite objects made of quarks held together by the strong force via the exchange of glue particles (gluons).  The structure of nucleons is a manifestation of that strongest force known to mankind. Although ninety-eight percent of the mass of ordinary matter is due to the strong force, the present theory of that force (Quantum Chromodynamics) is still not fully understood.  This research will help to advance our understanding.  The preparation of junior scientists plays a central role in the supported activities.

The study of the atomic nucleus and its constituents at the quark level is at the core of the research of the experimental nuclear physics group at the University of South Carolina. We have been leading experiments at one of the flagship facilities for nuclear physics research in the U.S., the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (JLab) and at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland. We have also been engaged in collaborative research at the J-PARC proton accelerator in Japan and the electron accelerator MAMI in Germany, and are responsible for the construction of critical equipment for major nuclear-physics experiments at JLab and PSI.

The strong force is one of the four fundamental forces of nature, the other three being gravity, electromagnetism, and the weak force. It governs the interaction of quarks and gluons that are the fundamental building blocks of protons and neutrons (also called nucleons). Nucleons are the constituents of nuclei, which are the foundation of living and non-living matter. While a lot of evidentiary record has been collected about the existence and the properties of nuclei, nucleons, and other particles composed of quarks and gluons, there are many remaining mysteries about the force acting between quarks and gluons the unraveling of which is critical for our understanding of the visible world.  Our studies focus on Quantum ChromoDynamics (QCD), humanity’s most advanced hypothesis of how the force between quark and gluons works.  The results from our research will ultimately help address fundamental questions such as: how is the visible mass in the universe generated, why do quarks and gluons not exist as free particles, what is the nature of neutron stars, and what are the properties of dense nuclear matter? Answering these questions is a complex task requiring dedicated experimental observations and careful testing of theoretical predictions against these observations.

A major outcome of this project is the measurement of large sets of observables for various nuclear reactions at JLab.  These novel high-precision results are used in theoretical fits to shed light on the excitation spectrum of nucleons.  In fact, one set of our published data was instrumental to establish evidence for a poorly known nucleon excited state.  Our results also drive the development of theoretical calculations to unveil details about the force acting between the quarks as they create ground and excited states. Other sets of published data provided quantitative insight into the lower energy limit of applicability of the quark-gluon description to strong phenomena involving light nuclei. While it is generally known that the force between a strange and an up quark is different from the force between an up and a down quark, we are lacking precise details on this broken symmetry. Our most recent results will be able to discriminate between different hypotheses about the numerical characteristics of these forces. We have also supported an important measurement searching for new physics beyond the Standard Model at the J-PARC facility.  The results will test lepton universality and could also reveal new exchange particles.

In addition to these scientific results we developed critical equipment for two forefront nuclear-physics experiments. We have designed, prototyped, and built the forward time-of-flight detector for CLAS12 experiments at JLab and achieved world-record time-of-flight resolutions for large scintillation counters. We have been instrumental in the development of the MUSE experiment at PSI for which we also prototyped and successfully tested scintillation detectors. We have written software to model experiments and detectors and to readout and calibrate detectors.
